results.title: At&T Inc. - Company Profile Report
results.content: In the US, the company has a notable market share in at least seven industries: Information, Movie & Video Production, Wireless Telecommunications Carriers, Wired Telecommunications Carriers, Internet Service Providers, Satellite TV Providers, Media Streaming, Social Networks and Other Content Providers and Movie & Video Production. Their largest market share is in the Satellite TV Providers industry, where they account for an estimated 53.7% of total industry revenue. Of the 3 core revenue-generating products and services in the Satellite TV Providers industry, At&T Inc. offers:. Of the 5 core revenue-generating products and services in the Wired Telecommunications Carriers industry, At&T Inc. offers:. Of the 4 core revenue-generating products and services in the Wireless Telecommunications Carriers industry, At&T Inc. offers:. Opportunities and Threats focus on external influences, and are based on trends and demand in the Satellite TV Providers , Wired Telecommunications Carriers , Wireless Telecommunications Carriers , Internet Service Providers , Media Streaming, Social Networks and Other Content Providers , Information , Movie & Video Production industries.

results.title: AT&T, Verizon, and the battle for the middle market
results.content: The competitive landscape up until now has stayed remarkably predictable: AT&T led in perception for large enterprises [1,000+ employees], Verizon the midsized market [20-999 employees], T-Mobile leveraged its consumer momentum to establish a beachhead in small business [<20 employees] and Comcast and Spectrum fighting for a seat at the table. Verizon is seen as having the most reliable network coverage overall, and this perception has positioned them to take market share from both AT&T and T-Mobile in the large business segment. T-Mobile has a commanding position as the perceived leader in the small business market, with the highest "complete experience" and "ease of use" scores. However, as T-Mobile tries to gain market share with midsize and large business segments, the consumer-focused "un-carrier" approach starts to fall apart, and a strategic shift is needed. Improving customer perception for mobile services through driving a better customer experience will help Comcast expand beyond the small business market.
